content: Somali insurgents fired mortars toward U.S. Congressman Donald Payne's plane during a visit to the Somali capital in Mogadishu. The New Jersey Democrat was not injured, his spokeswoman Kerry McKenney told FOX News. "One mortar landed at the airport when Payne's plane was due to fly and five others after he left and no one was hurt," Abukar Hassan, a police officer at Mogadishu airport, told Reuters. McKenney said Payne, who chairs the House subcommittee on Africa, felt it was important to go to Mogadishu and see first-hand what was happening there. His trip comes a day after U.S. sea captain Richard Phillips was rescued from four Somali pirates off Africa's eastern coast. more here: "http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,514935,00.html" "A government big enough to give you everything you want, is strong enough to take everything you have." ~ Gerald Ford
reply: Somali insurgents fired mortars toward U.S. Congressman Donald Payne's plane during a visit to the Somali capital in Mogadishu. The New Jersey Democrat was not injured, his spokeswoman Kerry McKenney told FOX News. "One mortar landed at the airport when Payne's plane was due to fly and five others after he left and no one was hurt," Abukar Hassan, a police officer at Mogadishu airport, told Reuters. McKenney said Payne, who chairs the House subcommittee on Africa, felt it was important to go to Mogadishu and see first-hand what was happening there. His trip comes a day after U.S. sea captain Richard Phillips was rescued from four Somali pirates off Africa's eastern coast. more here: "http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,514935,00.html" "A government big enough to give you everything you want, is strong enough to take everything you have." ~ Gerald Ford

content: quote: Originally posted by Anbar7: His trip comes a day after U.S. sea captain Richard Phillips was rescued from four Somali pirates off Africa's eastern coast. more here: "http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,514935,00.html" There is a UN-recognized Somali Transitional Federal Government which operates in exile in Djibouti, but who got started and even had influence around Mogadishu and a few neighbouring cities like Baidoa when the Ethiopian military invaded Somalia in 2007 to oust the Islamic Courts Union forces and local warlords. They were forced into exile when the Islamic insurgent forces overran Baidoa, though they obviously still have representatives on the ground in Mogadishu under the protection of the African Union peacekeeping force there (AMISOM), since some did meet US Congressman Payne when he visited Mogadishu. quote: BREAKING NEWS: Somali insurgents fire mortars at the plane of a US congressman visiting Mogadishu ++http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7996795.stm US politician targeted in Somalia Donald Payne was escorted by African Union peacekeepers A US congressman has had a narrow escape on a visit to Mogadishu after Somali insurgents fired mortars towards his plane as it was about to take off. Airport officials told the BBC one mortar had landed at the airport as Donald Payne's plane was due to fly and five others after his plane departed. Mr Payne had just met leaders of Somalia's government in the capital. He had discussed ways that the international community might be able to help war-torn Somalia. The BBC's Mohammed Olad Hassan in Mogadishu says Mr Payne had just held a half-hour news conference at the presidential palace in the capital when the attack happened... (...) Mr Payne had met President Sheikh Sharif Sheikh Ahmed and Prime Minister Omar Abdirashid Ali Sharmarke, among other Somali officials. The New Jersey Democrat said it was his first visit to Somalia since the early 1990s, when the country last had a stable government. Fragile government During his brief stop in one of the world's most dangerous cities, Mr Payne was escorted by African Union (AU) soldiers, who are deployed in Somalia on a peacekeeping mission. Radical Islamist guerrillas committed to toppling the fragile transitional federal government control parts of the capital and much of central and southern Somalia. Seventy-four-year-old Mr Payne is chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee's subcommittee on Africa and global health and a former head of the Congressional Black Caucus. The former top US diplomat for Africa, Jendayi Frazer, became the first high-ranking American official to visit Somalia in more than a decade when she landed in Baidoa in 2007, but the security situation kept her from visiting Mogadishu. US foreign policy on the Horn of Africa nation has been overshadowed by the killing of 18 US soldiers in Mogadishu in 1993. (...) This message has been edited. Last edited by: Canuck_Centaur, Tue 14 April 2009 12:22 AM
quote: Originally posted by Anbar7: His trip comes a day after U.S. sea captain Richard Phillips was rescued from four Somali pirates off Africa's eastern coast. more here: "http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,514935,00.html"
reply: There is a UN-recognized Somali Transitional Federal Government which operates in exile in Djibouti, but who got started and even had influence around Mogadishu and a few neighbouring cities like Baidoa when the Ethiopian military invaded Somalia in 2007 to oust the Islamic Courts Union forces and local warlords. They were forced into exile when the Islamic insurgent forces overran Baidoa, though they obviously still have representatives on the ground in Mogadishu under the protection of the African Union peacekeeping force there (AMISOM), since some did meet US Congressman Payne when he visited Mogadishu. quote: BREAKING NEWS: Somali insurgents fire mortars at the plane of a US congressman visiting Mogadishu ++http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7996795.stm US politician targeted in Somalia Donald Payne was escorted by African Union peacekeepers A US congressman has had a narrow escape on a visit to Mogadishu after Somali insurgents fired mortars towards his plane as it was about to take off. Airport officials told the BBC one mortar had landed at the airport as Donald Payne's plane was due to fly and five others after his plane departed. Mr Payne had just met leaders of Somalia's government in the capital. He had discussed ways that the international community might be able to help war-torn Somalia. The BBC's Mohammed Olad Hassan in Mogadishu says Mr Payne had just held a half-hour news conference at the presidential palace in the capital when the attack happened... (...) Mr Payne had met President Sheikh Sharif Sheikh Ahmed and Prime Minister Omar Abdirashid Ali Sharmarke, among other Somali officials. The New Jersey Democrat said it was his first visit to Somalia since the early 1990s, when the country last had a stable government. Fragile government During his brief stop in one of the world's most dangerous cities, Mr Payne was escorted by African Union (AU) soldiers, who are deployed in Somalia on a peacekeeping mission. Radical Islamist guerrillas committed to toppling the fragile transitional federal government control parts of the capital and much of central and southern Somalia. Seventy-four-year-old Mr Payne is chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee's subcommittee on Africa and global health and a former head of the Congressional Black Caucus. The former top US diplomat for Africa, Jendayi Frazer, became the first high-ranking American official to visit Somalia in more than a decade when she landed in Baidoa in 2007, but the security situation kept her from visiting Mogadishu. US foreign policy on the Horn of Africa nation has been overshadowed by the killing of 18 US soldiers in Mogadishu in 1993. (...) This message has been edited. Last edited by: Canuck_Centaur, Tue 14 April 2009 12:22 AM

content: quote: Originally posted by Motive25: Many people would call it "bravery", "courage", or "statesmanship". We are trying to rebuild a government there, and it would be a lot cheaper for us in the long run to rebuild their government and let it fight Al Qaeda and the pirates than to have us do it for them. All of what you say would be true, if this guy was an American, with the best interests of the country at heart - But he's a Democrat, and as Rush tells me, he was there to work with his terrorist allies - But they simply don't appreciate his willingness to surrender to them. Of course Congress will soon be voting on questions about this part of the world - We should tell them to stay in Washington, say their prayers, trust whatever the President tells them, and STFU! This is basically what Mr. Bush told Congress, and it's only fair that Mr. Obama be able to tell them the same thing. Some might whine and snivel that the President has too much power already. But they merely reference the Constitution - Of course we know better. Dave
